tossups.question: Edmund Wilson wrote that this author had “something like a great style, if there could be such a thing as a great style which was … not … applied to any subject at all.” This author wrote about the “inevitable thumb” that “slowly chafes its puckered index toward us” and “a kitten in the wilderness” in one poem. This author criticized The Waste Land as “so damned dead,” and attempted to write an epic positive counterpart to it. This poet of (*) “Chaplinesque” described his lover’s “argosy of bright hair” in a cycle of poems dedicated to Emil Opffer. He wrote about bells that “swing I know not where” and “the matrix of the heart” in his last poem, “The Broken Tower.” This poet described a seagull “Over the chained bay waters Liberty” in a ‘proem’ that opens his magnum opus. For 10 points, name this author of Voyages, “At Melville’s Tomb,” and The Bridge.

This person argued for using volunteer work to foster unity between the leader and the masses in a campaign to create the “New Man.” This person’s failed attempts to assist Laurent-Desire Kabila led him to call Kabila not “the man of the hour.” This person died while leading the Nancahuazu fighters with Tania against Rene Barrientos. This person spearheaded the creation of (*) “literacy brigades” during the “year of education.” A famous photograph of this person after the La Coubre explosion was taken by Alberto Korda. This man wrote a memoir of his travels with Alberto Granado called the Motorcycle Diaries and a manual on guerrilla warfare. Along with a future head of state, this person launched a revolution after travelling on the “Granma” to help topple Fulgencio Batista. For 10 points, name this comrade of Fidel Castro in the Cuban Revolution.

This poem’s author later disavowed it as “trash” and altered its meaning by changing “or” to “and” in its most famous line. This poem’s narrator wants to “undo the folded lie” of the “sensual man-in-the-street.” This poem’s narrator highlights “ironic points of light wherever the Just exchange their messages” and describes himself as “Eros” and “dust.” This poem says that (*) “exiled Thucydides (thu-SID-id-ees) knew all that a speech can say about Democracy” before dismissing “the windiest militant trash.” This poem describes its audience as “children afraid of the night who have never been happy or good.” This poem’s narrator sits “in one of the dives / on Fifty-second Street / Uncertain and afraid” and concludes “We must love one another or die.” For 10 points, name this W. H. Auden poem named for the date World War II began.

Algorithms for finding these things are tested on OptBench, which includes the LJ38 and Heptamer Island test cases. The “climbing image” method is a modification of an algorithm used to find these things which adds spring forces along a pathway. Lorquet’s nonadiabatic theory of these things allows for nonrelativistic coupling to cause mixed states. They are most commonly found using the synchronous transit or (*) nudged elastic band methods, and they resemble the end state closest in free energy to them according to Hammond’s postulate. They correspond to saddle points on a PES and are designated by a double dagger. The Arrhenius equation is used to find the energy of these things, which is called the activation energy. For 10 points, name these locally-maximal energy intermediates in a chemical reaction.

An aria by this composer was the inspiration for the lyrics of “O Superman” by Laurie Anderson. In one of this composer’s operas, a man demands that the protagonist dispose of a statuette of Eros before they are nearly stoned to death. In another of this man’s operas, three actresses reappear in various scenes, including a night of gambling that goes awry. The protagonist of that opera sings “Adieu, notre petite table” when she decides to betray her lover. That opera by this man ends with the death of a young woman in the arms of her former lover, (*) des Grieux, before she is to be deported. For the intermezzo of one of his operas, this composer symbolized the thoughts of a titular courtesan on the verge of conversion in an oft-performed concert piece called Meditation. For 10 points, name this composer of operas such as Thais (ta-is) and Manon.

During worship of Shiva, devotees often anoint themselves with this substance over parts of their body where the chakras are located; in that context, this substance is called vibhuti. Vaishnavites may use sandalwood paste in place of this substance to smear a “U” pattern. Kumkuma is a common red variety of this substance made from turmeric and slaked lime. Married women may adorn their (*) hair partitions using a form of this substance called sindoor. Shaivites form three white horizontal lines with this substance, which is smeared onto a person’s forehead to form a tilaka or tika (TEE-ka). In a legend that explains one use of this substance, Krishna used it to darken Radha’s fair skin, which later evolved into gopis festively spraying water containing this on each other. For 10 point, name this substance people throw at each other during Holi.
tossups.answer: powder [be generous with accepting answers as long as they describe something that resembles powder, like dust; accept ash; accept colors; accept kumkuma before mention; accept sindoor before mention; accept vibhuti before mention; prompt on “paint” or “pigment”]

tossups.question: After a politician with this surname was punched in the bathroom of a Long Island country club, Collier's Magazine created a golden “Toilet Seat Medal” to celebrate the anonymous assailant. The “pea patch politics” of a man with this surname are the subject of a book by his former crony Bill Dodd. A politician with this surname was opposed by a group of Standard Oil-backed legislators known as the “Dynamite Squad.” The stripper (*) Blaze Starr was the mistress of a politician with this surname who continued to serve as governor despite being committed to the state mental hospital by his wife. A politician with this surname was assassinated by the dentist Carl Weiss shortly after writing My First Days in the White House, a book that explains his populist “Share Our Wealth” ideology. For 10 points, give this shared surname of Louisiana governors Earl and Huey.
tossups.answer: Long [accept Huey Long or Earl Long]

tossups.question: In June 1982, the corpse of Banco Ambrosiano chairman Roberto Calvi was found hanging from a bridge over this river. Children nicknamed “mudlarks” would enter this river at low tide to scavenge its garbage. According to a John Burns quote, the “Mississippi is muddy water, but [this river] is liquid history.” This river regularly froze over during the Little Ice Age, allowing peasants to hold (*) “frost fairs” on its frozen surface. During the mid-19th century, a disease- and waste-infested portion of this river emitted a scent referred to as the “Great Stink.” George Frideric Handel composed the Water Music for a monarch’s pleasure barge outing on this river. Viking attacks on this river’s banks are the possible inspiration for a folk song that describes a bridge over it as “falling down, falling down.” For 10 points, name this river that flows through London.

A family of receptors for this compound also contains members that bind to adiponectin and are called PAQRs. Ulipristal acetate is a selective inhibitor of this compound’s receptors. This compound is converted to deoxycorticosterone by 21-alpha-hydroxylase and is synthesized by 3beta-HSD after side-chain cleavage of cholesterol. Devices called Skyla, Liletta, and Mirena elute an analog of this compound called levonorgestrel. A combination of a prostaglandin and an antagonist of this hormone’s receptor, (*) mifepristone, is used as emergency contraception. This hormone induces the formation of secretory endometrium after it is secreted by the corpus luteum post-ovulation. For 10 points, name this hormone found in combined oral contraceptive pills along with estrogen.

A work named for this ideology identifies it with the “species-consciousness” possessed by humanity and argues that it arises from the uniquely human ability to recognize oneself as both an I and a Thou. That work about this ideology is split into sections “in agreement with” and “in contradiction with” the human essence. Another work uses Benjamin Franklin’s writings on (*) thrift and the value of money to show the influence of this religion on moral attitudes toward industry and work. That work argues that this religion causes people to view their jobs as a “calling” and promotes economic growth. Ludwig Andreas Feuerbach wrote about the “essence” of this belief. For 10 points, name this religion whose ethic is said to have promoted the “spirit of capitalism” in a work by Max Weber (VAY-bur).
tossups.answer: Christianity [prompt on “religion”; accept more specific answers like “Protestantism”]

tossups.question: The mercenary pirate Eustace the Monk was executed in a battle while supporting this group in a conflict named for them. These people were damaged by their loss in the Battle of Sandwich after their two sieges of Dover were repulsed by Hubert de Burgh. That conflict named for this group was ended by the Treaty of Lambeth, also known as the Treaty of Kingston. This group crowned the future King Louis VIII at St. Paul’s Cathedral. These people were led by Robert (*) Fitzwalter in a conflict where they were defeated by William Marshal. Stephen Langton supported negotiations between this group and their monarch after he lost at the Battle of Bouvines, resulting in a document signed by these people at Runnymede in 1215. For 10 points, name this class of English landholders who signed the Magna Carta with King John.

In Japanese folklore, a girl from Matsuyama communes with her dead mother via one of these objects, which causes her stepmother to suspect her of witchcraft. It’s not an eye, but in one legend, Tsukuyomi was born from one of these things. In Greek myth, the Furies constantly show one of these objects to Orestes as they follow him. One of these objects is hung from a tree along with jewels and white clothes after roosters crow and a goddess makes the other gods (*) laugh with a lewd dance. After his foot was eaten by Cipactli, one god replaced his foot with an obsidian one of these items. Amaterasu was lured out of her cave by one of these objects placed by its entrance, and Tezcatlipoca was named after a “smoking” variety of this object. To avoid looking at the head of Medusa, Perseus used Athena’s shield as, for 10 points, what kind of reflective object?

An integral-differential equation in the time domain can be used to analyze the behavior of a system undergoing the hysteretic type of this phenomenon. Another method for determining the extent of this phenomenon involves calculating the logarithmic decrement. For a series RLC circuit, the coefficient describing this process equals one over the resistance times the (*) square root of the inductance over the capacitance. One quantity that describes the effect of this phenomenon equals two pi times the ratio of energy stored to energy dissipated per cycle and is known as the Q factor. When the coefficient describing this phenomenon is equal to the resonant frequency, it occurs in a critical fashion. For 10 points, name this phenomenon which reduces the amplitude of a harmonic oscillator over time.

One founder of this movement was inspired by Theosophy to create near-mirrored figures in Dancers, and he expressed the ideas that led to his break from this movement in Rhythm of a Russian Dance. Another artist in this movement designed Miss Blanche Virginia cigarette advertisements and used spiraling composition in Mechano-Dancer. One artist in this movement wrote that “the life of modern cultured man is gradually turning away from the natural” and produced diamond-shaped paintings called (*) lozenges with white backgrounds and black section borders. This movement produced a painting consisting of grid patterns in red, yellow, blue, and grey; that painting is Broadway Boogie Woogie. For 10 points, name this Dutch geometric art movement also known as neoplasticism, whose members included Theo van Doesburg and Piet Mondrian.
tossups.answer: De Stijl [or The Style, accept Neoplasticism until read]

tossups.question: The narrator of this work reminisces about watching sand flow through an hourglass before remembering a white building with inscriptions and pitting his moral sense against the benefits of chaos. A two-part work inspired by this novella features a journalist who parties with Laura before another narrator, possibly the same man, visits Varanasi; that work is by Geoff Dyer. This novella’s protagonist is an author who observes a “lady in pearls” and dreams about an orgy worshipping “the stranger god.” This work’s protagonist smells (*) disinfectant and is warned about sirocco, which is a cover-up for a cholera epidemic. He gets sick from eating bad strawberries and watches the Polish boy Tadzio on the beach before collapsing in his chair. For 10 points, name this novella about Gustav von Aschenbach’s demise in the title city by Thomas Mann.
tossups.answer: Death in Venice [or Der Tod in Venedig]

tossups.question: Richard Wagner (VOG-ner) composed a piece for wind ensemble called Trauermusik for the burial of this composer in Dresden. One work by this composer begins with the soloist entering on a high concert E-flat and immediately dropping three octaves to low concert E-flat; that woodwind concertante work was dedicated to Heinrich Baermann. This man turned his planned third piano concerto into a program work depicting (*) a maiden waiting for her lover to return from the crusades. Hector Berlioz orchestrated the second-act ballet of this composer’s most famous opera that was based on his Invitation to the Dance. For 10 points, name this composer who is best known for his operatic works such as Euryanthe and Der Freischutz.

A forged history of this ruler was likely written to increase the popularity of the Carmine de Santiago; that work about this ruler was written by Archbishop Turpin. Belgian historian Henri Pirenne stated that this leader “would be inconceivable” without Muhammad. A biographer of this ruler supposedly eloped to Seligenstadt with this ruler’s daughter, Emma, and took inspiration from Suetonius’ The Twelve Caesars. Under the sponsorship of this ruler, the Historia Langobardorum was written by (*) Paul the Deacon. This ruler commissioned four books refuting the 2nd Council of Nicaea by Theodulf. Walafrid Strabo modified a biography of this ruler. Alcuin of York joined this ruler’s court, and a biography of him was written by Einhard. For 10 points, name this Frankish ruler whose ambush in Roncevaux Pass provided the basis for the Song of Roland.
tossups.answer: Charlemagne [or Charles I; Charles the Great; prompt on partial answers]

tossups.question: One theorem in this field states that under certain hypotheses, if a function g is strictly smaller than a function f on the boundary of a region, then f and f plus g have the same number of zeroes in that region. The fundamental theorem of algebra can be proven as a corollary of a theorem from this field by arguing that the reciprocal of a polynomial with no zeroes would have to be bounded, and thus (*) constant. The main objects of study in this field satisfy the relations u sub x equals v sub y and u sub y equals negative v sub x. Those are the Cauchy-Riemann equations, which determine when a function is analytic, or equivalently holomorphic. For 10 points, name this branch of mathematics that extends the results of real analysis to functions over C.

ARCH and GARCH conditions indicate that error terms for data points are correlated with other error terms that differ in this variable. In the weak efficient markets hypothesis, the rate of return of an asset is independent of this variable. A stationary process’ statistical properties do not change with changes in this variable. The two components of an option’s value are the intrinsic value and the [this] value. The (*) auto-regressive integrated moving average, or ARIMA, is a common model applied to plots with this variable as the x-axis. Stock and flow variables measure quantities in relation to this variable. Effects in longitudinal studies and longitudinal data are observed over changes in this variable. For 10 points, name this variable used in forecasting models in a namesake “series” from econometrics.

A woman with this attribute escapes being raped by the Grand Duke by jumping into a Fabergé egg and is interviewed by journalist Jack Walser, who follows her to Siberia. A man with this attribute disappoints people by speaking in an “incomprehensible dialect with a strong sailor’s voice” instead of Latin and is visited by a woman who ran out of numbers while counting her heartbeats and a man who can’t sleep because of the noise of the stars. The “Cockney Venus,” trapeze artist Sophie Fevvers, has this physical feature in Angela Carter’s Nights at the Circus. A (*) spider girl steals the audience of a man with this unusual physical feature, who is imprisoned in a chicken coop after being found in the mud by Elisenda and Pelayo. For 10 points, name these body parts, which title a Gabriel Garcia Marquez story about “A Very Old Man with Enormous” ones.
tossups.answer: having wings [prompt on being able to “fly”] Bonuses:

bonuses.leadin: This theory uses Ashtekar variables to rewrite the Hamiltonian constraint in polynomial form. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: loop quantum gravity [or LQG; prompt on partial answer]
non-renormalizable [accept any answers indicating renormalization being impossible]
parts: Name this theory that claims that space is composed of spin networks that are quantized in units of the Planck length. Unlike string theory, this theory does not contain supersymmetry.
Loop quantum gravity attempts to combine quantum mechanics and this field. Gravity is described in this field by the Einstein field equations.
LQG attempts to solve this problem with quantum field theories of gravity. Gravity has this property since an infinite number of coupling constants are needed to remove the divergences.

bonuses.leadin: This book lays out the idea of the episteme, the historical groundings of knowledge and discourse within a particular epoch. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: The Order of Things [or Les Mots et les choses or The Words and the things]
parts: Name this poststructuralist work on the origins of fields like biology, economics, and linguistics. It opens by discussing Velazquez’s Las Meninas.
The Order of Things is by this French philosopher, who also wrote Madness and Civilization and Discipline and Punish.

Diana Taylor and Nancy Fraser have both critiqued Foucault’s work as paradoxical. This other thinker argued that Foucault was a “crypto-normativist” who relied on Enlightenment principles while trying to refute them.

bonuses.leadin: This event began as an ill-conceived crusade created by Tamas Bakocz. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Dozsa (DOE-ja) rebellion [the leader’s name is Gyorgy Dozsa; prompt on “Szekely”]
Leo X [or Giovanni di Lorenzo de Medici]
parts: Name this peasant revolt during the reign of Wladislaw II that was crushed by John Zapolya at Temesvar. The namesake leader of this event was fed to fellow rebels while being cooked on an iron throne.

This pope originally endorsed the Dozsa rebellion. This pope is better known for being given an elephant named Hanno by Manuel I of Portugal, closing the Fifth Lateran Council, and publishing the bull Exsurge Domine.
The Dozsa rebellion occurred in this region of Romania, which was to the north of Wallachia. This “land beyond the woods” was ruled by voivodes like Stephen Bathory and John Zapolya.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name some high-brow cultural references from Mr. Bean movies.
answers_sanitized: Arrangement in Grey and Black No. 1 [or Whistler’s Mother, accept anything indicating Whistler’s portrait of his mother]
parts: In the first movie, Mr. Bean accidentally ruins this painting of an old woman and is forced to replace it with a poster. He successfully gives an improvised speech on how this painting portrays the importance of family.
In Mr. Bean’s Holiday, Mr. Bean accidentally hijacks a movie premiere during this Film Festival on his way to a Southern beach in France.
Upon being stranded in a French town with no money, Mr. Bean’s performance of this emotional soprano aria from Gianni Schicchi earns him a standing ovation and enough money to take a bus.

bonuses.leadin: Name some painters from their descriptions by Victorian art critic John Ruskin, for 10 points each:
parts: Ruskin praised the “awful but glorious light” of the sunset and the “dark, fantastic forms” of the sea in this painter’s Slave Ship. He was pretty obsessed with this painter of Rain, Steam, and Speed.

Ruskin defended this Pre-Raphaelite artist who showed a lower-class carpenter shop in Christ in the House of his Parents. He also married Ruskin’s wife, Effie Gray, after Ruskin failed to consummate their marriage.

Ruskin excoriated this Italian Baroque painter, calling him everything that will “sink humanity to Hell.” This landscape painter created Self-Portrait as Philosopher of Silence and Odysseus and Nausicaa.

bonuses.leadin: A prime p can be written as the sum of two squares if and only if it has this property. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: congruent to 1 modulo 4 [or 1 mod 4 or leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 4 or anything equivalent]
parts: Name this property. Negative one is a quadratic residue modulo p if and only if p has this property.

That fact about primes congruent to 1 mod 4 is a consequence of this more general theorem that describes the conditions under which a given number is a quadratic residue modulo p. It is often formulated in terms of the Legendre symbol.
Quadratic reciprocity was first proven by this mathematician, who went on to publish six proofs of it. He also lends his name to the normal distribution.

bonuses.leadin: This figure is uncannily similar to Cyclops from the X-Men because she can fry things with her eyes, which were nearly always blindfolded. For ten points each:
parts: Name this legendary woman who gave birth to a lump of gray flesh, which was then divided into one hundred pieces and incubated in jars, then born as her children. This woman’s first child was Duryodhana.
The near-invincible Duryodhana, whose body was strengthened by his mother’s powerful gaze, was one of one hundred brothers collectively known by this name. Their story is told in the Mahabharata.
This figure, an avatar of Vishnu, aids the Pandavas in their fight against the Kauravas. He is Arjuna’s charioteer.

bonuses.leadin: This author’s characters include a postman who hides a letter about a death and a monk who befriends a tiger. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Indian author, who fictionalized his youth, adolescence, and marriage in books like Swami and Co. and The English Teacher. Those works, like his novel The Guide, are set in the fictional town of Malgudi.

In this Narayan novel, the title calligrapher, Raman, is estranged from his conservative aunt when he works for and falls in love with the progressive social worker Daisy, who runs away right before their marriage.

This writer of Brighton Rock and The Power and the Glory helped Narayan get published. He wrote about James Wormold, who sends fake spy reports with vacuum cleaner schematics to the MI6, in Our Man in Havana.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the history of human zoos in the United States:
answers_sanitized: P. T. Barnum [or Phineas Taylor Barnum]
St. Louis World’s Fair [or the 1904 World’s Fair; or the Louisiana Purchase Exhibition; prompt on “1904 Summer Olympics” or “St. Louis Summer Olympics”]
parts: This showman displayed “Zip the Pinhead,” the Siamese twins Chang and Eng, and a bearded lady named Josephine in his museum. This co-owner of a circus with James Bailey said, “There’s a sucker born every minute.”

One of P. T. Barnum’s best-known “freaks” was the dwarf Charles Stratton, who famously had this alliterative two-word nickname. This was also the name of a locomotive Peter Cooper designed for the B & O Railroad.

Ota Benga, a Congolese pygmy held in the Bronx Zoo, was displayed with Geronimo in a human zoo at this event. This event included a reenactment of the Second Boer War and the talking horse Beautiful Jim Key.

bonuses.leadin: Although he is not Handel, this composer created an orchestral suite called Water Music to celebrate the centennial of Hamburg admiralty. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Baroque composer and godfather of C.P.E. Bach. He may be best known for composing three sets of chamber pieces designed to accompany a meal called Tafelmusik.

Many of Telemann’s vocal works exemplify this style in their simplicity and lack of virtuosic ornamentation. This style was a response to the complexity of late Baroque and was pioneered by Luigi Boccherini and C.P.E Bach.
Telemann is thought to be the first to compose a concerto for this stringed instrument that is pitched exactly one-fifth lower than a violin.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name these things that the writer encountered in their time on the Halal Memes for Jannah-Minded Teens Page.
answers_sanitized: paradise (accept heaven or other obvious equivalents)
parts: In the title of the meme group, Jannah refers to what concept in Islam? This place is described as garden-like and filled with amazing food and drink.
Many halal memes deal with making [this thing], usually for other members of the ummah, including potential spouses. This term refers to a type of supplication and literally means “invocation.”
Various memes discuss the measly-ness and bad taste of this type of food that is used to break fasts during Ramadan.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about commercial sailing ships, for 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: carracks [or carraca; nau; caraque; nef; kraak]
Zheng He [or Cheng Ho; Ma He]
parts: These boats created by the Arabs had triangular lateen sails and conducted commerce on the Red Sea and Indian Ocean. The hulls of these ships were sewn together with fiber.
These merchant ships developed by the Portuguese were the oceangoing complements to caravels. They typically had three or four masts and could displace more than a thousand tons.
Chinese junks were among the enormous treasure ships used by this Ming dynasty eunuch to travel around Asia to gain tribute from varied powers.

bonuses.leadin: One woman in this play exclaims that “libraries are vile places!” which probably explains her use of phrases like “she’s as headstrong as an allegory on the banks of the Nile.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: a folding screen [prompt on descriptive answers like “room divider,” do not accept or prompt on “curtain”]
parts: Name this play, in which the comic Mrs. Malaprop is the guardian of Lydia Languish, who falls in love with “Ensign Beverley,” actually Jack Absolute in disguise.

This 18th-century British playwright of The Rivals also wrote about the malicious Lady Sneerwell spreading rumors about an affair between Lady Teazle and the profligate Charles Surface in The School for Scandal.

In the fourth act of The School for Scandal, Lady Teazle hides behind one of these objects after Joseph tries to seduce her and tells her husband Peter a “little French milliner” is behind it, leading him to look.

bonuses.leadin: This place was also called Ammonium because it was the seat for the oracle of Amon. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Egyptian location where Alexander the Great deified himself. Cambyses II supposedly lost his army when they were buried by a sandstorm while attempting to conquer this location.
Alexander the Great’s deification did not prevent him from dying in this city, as prophesied by the seer Calanus. Hammurabi was a king of this city, which was also home to the Hanging Gardens.
Before dying, Alexander the Great invaded India up to the Beas River after winning this battle against King Porus of Punjab. Alexander’s renowned horse Bucephalus allegedly died in this battle.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the theory of structuration, for 10 points each:
parts: Structuration theory was fleshed out in this British sociologist’s The Constitution of Society. He was also the major academic thinker behind the “Third Way” Labour Party framework that characterized Tony Blair’s policy.

Structuration theory’s model of human agency centers on this type of figure, who reflexively analyzes their own conduct. Goffman compared people to members of this profession in his dramaturgical approach.
Structuration theory builds upon the “action frame of reference” of this American sociologist but rejects part of his structural functionalist approach from The Structure of Social Action.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some things about bacteriophages, for 10 points each:
parts: This phage was first discovered by Esther Lederberg when she noticed that shining it with UV light induced it to enter the lytic cycle. The cos sequence from this phage is used for phage transduction of cosmids.

This phage can only replicate through the lytic cycle. A relative of this T-even bacteriophage was used by Hershey and Chase for their experiment, and a commonly used DNA ligase is isolated from this bacteriophage.

This scientist was the first to notice the phenomenon of multiplicity reactivation, in which two bacteriophages infect and recombine within the same bacterium. He names a fluctuation test with Delbruck.

bonuses.leadin: This kinetic sculpture was presented in a display that lasted half an hour before the fire department shut it down, leaving the spectators to scavenge for its remnants. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: lobster trap [accept “Lobster Trap and Fish Tail,” prompt on “lobster” or “trap”]
parts: Name this Jean Tinguely sculpture made out of junk like a weather balloon, bicycle parts, and old motors, which made a lot of noise before self-destructing.
This artist was famous for his kinetic sculptures, known as mobiles. He also created stabiles such as the bright red Flamingo in Chicago.
Calder’s most famous mobile is named after one of these objects and a fish tail. It features a striped red oval above a wire mesh and a series of black scales.

bonuses.leadin: This novel proposes that the “Kilroy was here” graffiti was originally a circuit diagram of a band-pass filter. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel in which the “human yo-yo” Benny Profane meets up with the “Whole Sick Crew,” and Herbert Stencil tries to find the title entity, which is reincarnated as various women.
This reclusive postmodernist author of V. also wrote about Tyrone Slothrop’s sexual encounters foreshadowing V2 rocket strikes in Gravity’s Rainbow.
In this Pynchon short story which inspired a chapter of V., the spy Porpentine meets his partner Goodfellow for coffee before being killed under the Sphinx when his boss Moldweorp turns against him.

bonuses.leadin: This compound is commonly used as paint thinner, and hippuric acid levels in the blood rise when someone is poisoned with it. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: ortho and para [do not accept or prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this compound that consists of a benzene ring with a methyl group attached. Its trinitro derivative is a powerful explosive.
Methyl groups direct addition to these two positions on the benzene ring. Name both.
Benzyl bromide can be synthesized from toluene using this reagent combined with NBS. This radical initiator contains a nitrogen-nitrogen double bond and two C-N triple bonds.

bonuses.leadin: This character originally refers to women as “the lower race” but can’t get along without them, and he eats a watermelon after having sex. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character who falls in love with Anna in Yalta and realizes that “the most complicated and difficult part of it was only just beginning” after meeting her again.

Dmitri Gurov and Anna Sergeyevna are characters in “The Lady with the Dog,” a story by this Russian author of The Cherry Orchard and Uncle Vanya, whose principle of dramatic economy is called his “gun.”

In this Chekhov short story, a man makes the title agreement to stay in jail for fifteen years in exchange for two million rubles. He spends the years reading, grows to despise humanity, and leaves five hours before his time is up.
